close_symbols: recv_cls (the function-pointer type / prototype used in struct MHD_Connection)
read_buffer (the declared type of the read_buffer field in struct MHD_Connection)
ssize_t (typedef / header where it is defined)
size_t (typedef / header where it is defined)
MHD_Pool (type of connection->pool, if distinct from void*)
explanation:
• struct MHD_Connection (complete definition): needed to see the exact declared types of all pointer members accessed here (especially read_buffer, daemon, pool, and the recv_cls field). The MISRA rule concerns whether these pointer types are or could be declared const; only the struct definition shows current const-qualification of members.

• recv_cls (the function-pointer type / prototype used in struct MHD_Connection): the code calls connection->recv_cls(connection, buffer, size). To decide whether the buffer argument should be a pointer-to-const or not we must know the recv_cls parameter types (e.g. void *buf vs const void *buf) and whether the callback promises to modify the buffer — if recv_cls already requires a non-const destination parameter, then marking the buffer const would be incorrect.

• read_buffer (the declared type of the read_buffer field in struct MHD_Connection): while part of the struct, highlight it because the buffer is passed as the write target. Its declared type (char *, unsigned char *, void *, or const char *) determines whether current code violates or respects the const-pointer guideline.

• MHD_pool_reallocate (prototype/signature): the function is called with the existing read_buffer pointer and returns a pointer. The parameter types and return type (e.g. void *MHD_pool_reallocate(MHD_Pool *, void *, size_t, size_t)) determine whether passing connection->read_buffer is compatible with const qualification and whether the function expects/returns const-qualified pointers.

• ssize_t (typedef / header): bytes_read is ssize_t and is cast to size_t later; need the exact typedef to reason about signed/unsigned conversions that can affect whether pointers or buffer lengths are treated as modifiable or const—also to understand whether buffer length parameters are size_t.

• size_t (typedef / header): used for buffer sizes and offsets; knowing its typedef is necessary to reason about parameter types of functions called (recv_cls, MHD_pool_reallocate) and whether const qualification on pointer-to-size arguments is relevant.

• bool (stdbool.h / definition of true/false): used for connection->suspended, discard_request, read_closed — to confirm these are plain booleans and not const-qualified pointers; helps ensure that suggestions to make pointers const don’t conflict with boolean members.

• MHD_Pool (type of connection->pool, if distinct from void*): MHD_pool_reallocate takes the pool argument; if the pool type and API impose const-correctness constraints on the buffer pointer, that affects whether read_buffer can/should be const.

Rationale summary: to decide whether any pointer in MHD_connection_handle_read should point to a const-qualified type, the analyzer must know the declared types (and const qualifiers) of the struct fields used and the exact prototypes of called functions that accept or return those pointers. The items above provide the minimal additional type and prototype information required to determine if const-qualification is possible or already present, and whether changing it would be compatible with the APIs used.
